title: Hong Kong-Style French Toast

Directions
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 200ºF (93ºC). Set a wire rack in a rimmed baking sheet. Arrange bread in a single layer on the rack and cook in oven, turning once, until dried but not toasted, about 10 minutes. Transfer to a plate and line a separate plate with a double layer of paper towels. Set baking sheet aside.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together eggs, sugar, and salt until thoroughly combined. Add milk and whisk to blend.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
In a large Dutch oven or wok, add oil until it measures 2 inches deep and heat over high heat to 350ºF (177ºC). Meanwhile, lay 4 slices of bread out on a work surface and spread each slice with 2 tablespoons peanut butter , then top each with a slice of bread.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Whisk egg mixture to recombine, then, working with 1 sandwich at a time, soak sandwich in egg mixture, flipping as needed, until saturated, about 2 minutes. Allow any excess egg mixture to drip into the bowl, then carefully add soaked sandwich to hot oil and fry until golden brown on bottom side, about 2 minutes. Using tongs and/or spider skimmer, gently flip the sandwich and continue to fry until golden brown on the other side, about 2 minutes. Transfer the French toast to the prepared plate, then place on wire rack and keep warm in the oven. Return oil to 350ºF (177ºC)  and repeat with remaining sandwiches.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Divide the French toast among four plates, top with pats of butter and a generous drizzle of condensed milk. Serve.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Special Equipment
Wire rack, rimmed baking sheet, large Dutch oven or wok, instant-read thermometer, tongs and/or spider skimmer
Notes
White sandwich bread may be substituted for milk bread or brioche, but I recommend using a soft, enriched bread for best results.
Make-Ahead and Storage
Hong Kong-style French toast should be eaten immediately.
